chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of tuberculosis
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with suspected active tuberculosis in primary care, and the principles of specialist management for people with confirmed active tuberculosis.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a person has suspected active tuberculosis (TB) infection, arrange admission or referral for specialist assessment and management depending on clinical judgement:
    • Arrange hospital admission if the person is very symptomatic, systemically unwell, or has complex social needs such as homelessness.
    • Arrange urgent referral to the local multidisciplinary TB team for confirmation of the diagnosis and ongoing management, if hospital admission is not needed.
      • Do not delay specialist referral by waiting for culture results if symptoms are highly suggestive of active TB.
  • If a person has known active or latent TB but has not completed treatment as planned (for example treatment has been interrupted or stopped due to adverse effects or complex clinical or social needs):
    • Arrange hospital admission if the person is symptomatic or systemically unwell.
    • Arrange urgent re-referral to the local multidisciplinary TB team to re-establish treatment, if hospital admission is not needed.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist assessment and management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Tuberculosis (TB) is a notifiable disease. A clinician (usually a TB specialist) should notify a new culture-confirmed case of TB, or where TB is suspected and a decision has been made to treat the person, within 3 working days [PHE, 2014].

Specialist assessment

  • Rapid diagnostic nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) for the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex may be used on primary specimens if there is clinical suspicion of TB and the person has HIV, or a rapid diagnosis and information about mycobacterial species is needed, or contact tracing of large numbers of people may be needed.
  • Alternative sampling and imaging techniques may be needed in addition to those available in primary care, such as sputum induction, bronchoscopy and lavage, gastric aspiration, organ-specific aspiration or biopsy, and CT or MRI scans.

Specialist management

  • If a diagnosis of active TB is suspected on the basis of clinical features, specialist treatment should be started without waiting for the culture results:
    • Antibiotic drug treatment with combination regimens — usually 6 months of isoniazid (with pyridoxine) and rifampicin, supplemented in the first 2 months with pyrazinamide and ethambutol. Treatment success is usually defined by completion of therapy with negative follow-up sputum smears. People with active TB of the central nervous system require a prolonged treatment regimen. Drug susceptibility testing may result in the modification of treatment regimens.
    • Treatment of multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB — this is more complex than standard treatment, often involving prolonged treatment (for 18–24 months) with at least six drugs to which the mycobacterium is likely to be sensitive. Treatment is often less efficacious and more poorly tolerated due to increased adverse effects.
    • Surgical management of MDR and extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB — candidates for surgery may include people with potentially resectable unilateral disease (or apical bilateral disease in selected cases), with adequate lung function who have not responded to medical treatment.
  • Care should be co-ordinated through the local multidisciplinary TB team including a key worker to support and encourage the person to complete treatment successfully, monitor adherence to treatment, check clinical response, and identify any adverse effects. Care of the person should include:
    • Initiating immediate contact tracing.
    • Enhanced case management (a package of individualized supportive care) for people with clinically or socially complex needs considered to be at high risk of poor adherence to treatment (for example people who are homeless, history of drug misuse; previous TB treatment; MDR TB; recently or currently living in prison; significant mental health, memory, or cognitive problems; HIV infection; or are unable to take TB medication unassisted).
      • This may include 'directly observed therapy' (DOT), where drug treatment is given under the observation of a key worker and the person is observed to swallow each dose of medication, or 'video observed therapy' (VOT), to improve adherence, reduce the risk of stopping treatment early, and reduce drug resistance.
    • An individual health and social care plan including provision for unmet social needs and psychological support.
    • Infection control measures if a person has suspected or confirmed pulmonary or laryngeal TB.
      • These may include respiratory hygiene measures (such as covering the mouth when coughing and disposing of tissues), and wearing a face mask, until they have had at least two weeks of TB treatment.
    • A risk assessment for drug-resistant TB and HIV infection.
    • Education about TB, its transmission, and treatment, including the fact that treatment is confidential and free for all people, irrespective of eligibility for other NHS care.
    • Co-ordinated discharge planning.
    • Liaison with other clinical teams, such as HIV, respiratory, infectious disease, and public health specialists.

[Millard, 2015; Whittaker, 2015; BTS, 2016; Dheda, 2016; NICE, 2016; WHO, 2016; Bracchi, 2018; Migliori, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to refer people with suspected tuberculosis (TB) are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Tuberculosis. Prevention, diagnosis, management and service organisation [NICE, 2016], the British HIV Association (BHIVA) Guidelines for the management of tuberculosis in adults living with HIV 2018 [Bracchi, 2018], the Public Health England (PHE) publications Guidance on notifying tuberculosis (TB) cases [PHE, 2014], Health matters: reducing the burden of tuberculosis [PHE, 2016], and Reports of cases of tuberculosis to enhanced tuberculosis surveillance systems: UK, 2000 to 2017 [PHE, 2018b]; and expert opinion in review articles on pulmonary TB [Campbell and Bah-Sow, 2006] and TB [Hartman-Adams, 2014; Millard, 2015; Dheda, 2016].

Management of suspected active TB infection
  • The recommendations on admission or referral for people with suspected active infection are extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2016] and the PHE publication [PHE, 2016].
    • The NICE clinical guideline notes that people with suspected infectious or confirmed pulmonary TB should not be admitted to hospital for diagnostic tests or care unless there is a clear clinical or public health need (for example the person is homeless).
    • Urgent referral is recommended, as a key element in the control of TB infection is the rapid diagnosis of active cases. This can lead to reduced opportunities for onward transmission, better treatment outcomes, reduced development of drug-resistant TB, and reduced health and social inequalities [PHE, 2016].
    • This is supported by expert opinion in a review article which states that treating people at home is no more likely to lead to cross-infection than treatment in hospital [Campbell and Bah-Sow, 2006].
  • The recommendation not to delay referral and specialist treatment while awaiting culture results is based on the NICE clinical guideline.
Management of incompletely treated latent or active TB infection
  • This recommendation is extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline which gives guidance on re-establishing TB treatment after interruptions, for example due to hepatotoxic or cutaneous adverse effects [NICE, 2016]. It is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be safe clinical practice.
Specialist assessment and management of confirmed TB
  • The requirement to notify new cases of suspected or active TB that meet specific criteria is based on the PHE publication on notifying TB cases [PHE, 2014].
    • Notification allows for a timely risk assessment of cases and their contacts by clinical and public health teams. In addition, patient demographic data of new cases is entered into the Enhanced Tuberculosis Surveillance scheme to allow epidemiological surveillance of the disease in England, Wales, and northern Ireland [PHE, 2018b].
  • The information on the role and organization of specialist TB services is largely based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2016], the BHIVA guidelines [Bracchi, 2018], and expert opinion in a review article [Millard, 2015].
    • The BHIVA guidelines state that the risk of developing TB is estimated to be between 26 and 31 times greater in people with HIV than the general population. It recommends that all people with TB should therefore be tested for HIV, regardless of their risk factors, as increasing numbers of people with TB are co-infected with HIV in the UK.
    • Individualized and for some people, enhanced case management, is essential to deliver, monitor, and encourage adherence to drug treatment regimens. In addition, individual case plans are designed to help recognise and manage adverse effects from treatment and provide psychosocial support. If this is not in place, drug adherence rates are reduced resulting in treatment failure and relapse, TB transmission to others, and the development of further TB drug and multidrug resistance [Millard, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What self-management advice should I give?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a person has confirmed active tuberculosis (TB) infection and is undergoing specialist management:

  • Provide sources of information, advice, and support for the person and parents/carers, such as:
    • The national TB charity 'TB Alert' (www.tbalert.org) which campaigns to raise awareness of TB, and advocates for improved TB services in the UK and worldwide. This hosts a TB information website 'The Truth about TB' (available at www.thetruthabouttb.org) which provides peer support and information leaflets on the diagnosis and treatment of TB, including latent TB, multidrug-resistant TB, contact tracing, and screening.
    • The Public Health England (PHE) information leaflet Tuberculosis: the disease, its treatment and prevention.
    • The patient information leaflet Tuberculosis available on the www.patient.info website.
  • Encourage adherence to the treatment regimen.
    • Explain that TB is treatable and curable if treatment is completed as advised by the local multidisciplinary TB team.
  • Advise on healthy lifestyle measures, including stopping smoking and not drinking excessive alcohol.
    • See the CKS topics on Smoking cessation and Alcohol - problem drinking for more information.
  • Provide additional psychosocial support if needed, including management of anxiety and/or depression.
    • See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder, Depression in children, and Depression for more information.
  • Advise that pulmonary or laryngeal TB can be transmitted to close contacts, and screening via contact tracing will be arranged by the local multidisciplinary TB team for high-risk contacts.
  • Advise on symptoms suggesting relapse after treatment completion and the need to inform the local multidisciplinary TB team or primary care immediately, if the person develops symptoms suggesting possible treatment failure or re-infection.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on self-management are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Tuberculosis. Prevention, diagnosis, management and service organisation [NICE, 2016], the World Health Organization (WHO) publication Global Tuberculosis Report 2018 [WHO, 2018b], the European Respiratory Society (ERS)/European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) Statement European Union standards for tuberculosis care, 2017 update [Migliori, 2018], the Public Health England (PHE) publication Health matters: reducing the burden of tuberculosis [PHE, 2016], and expert opinion in review articles [Chiang et al, 2007; Dheda, 2016; Behr, 2018].

Encouraging adherence to TB treatment
  • The recommendations on encouraging adherence to treatment are based on the NICE clinical guideline which states that the importance of adherence to treatment should be emphasized [NICE, 2016].
  • Completing a full course of treatment is important to reduce the risk of medical complications for the person, reduce the risk of transmission to others, and reduce the risk of multidrug-resistant TB developing. The WHO reports a global TB treatment success rate of 82% in 2016 [WHO, 2018b]. 
Providing information and support
  • The recommendations on providing information and support to affected people, parents and/or carers is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2016] and the PHE publication [PHE, 2016].
Advice on lifestyle measures
  • The recommendation on smoking is based on a review article which states that both passive and active exposure to tobacco smoke has been shown to be associated with TB infection and with the transition from initial infection to developing active TB disease. In addition, smoking has been found to be associated with relapse of TB infection. It concludes that people with TB 'need and should receive counselling and assistance in stopping smoking' [Chiang et al, 2007]. This is supported by expert opinion in a review article that smoking is a risk factor for TB infection [Dheda, 2016].
  • The recommendation on alcohol consumption is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Providing psychosocial support
  • This recommendation is extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline, which states that the person's TB key worker should make an individual health and social plan to help identify unmet needs, help the person engage with services, and complete TB treatment [NICE, 2016].
Information on contact tracing
  • The information on contact tracing is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2016], the ERS/ECDC Statement on TB care [Migliori, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles [Dheda, 2016; Behr, 2018].
Providing information on symptoms of relapse after completing treatment
  • This recommendation is based on the NICE clinical guideline, which highlights the need for people who have completed TB treatment to be aware of symptoms of relapse and how to contact the local multidisciplinary TB team [NICE, 2016].
